Barack Obama's presidential campaign has sparked plenty of discussion about race in American politics and in American life.

The fact is that the comments that have been made reflect the complexities of race in this country that we've never really worked through, a part of our union that we have not yet made perfect.

As NPR's Celeste Headlee reports, Obama's candidacy brings out some conflicted feelings among African-Americans.
Let's be clear.
No one we spoke to for this story suggests there's a dearth of support for Barack Obama among African-Americans.

What we're seeing here is what we regard as extremely solid black support for Democratic candidates, really getting about as close to unanimous as you're going to get in a free election.
But since Obama clinched the Democratic nomination, some African-Americans have expressed a sense of unease about his candidacy.

He says along with a feeling of pride and enthusiasm, some blacks also feel nervous.

If Obama's elected, what will the response of the country be?
Williams says if Obama wins, he'll immediately be faced with serious issues of high gas and food prices, an unpopular war in Iraq, and climate change.
